I don't know about Florida but here in California I get Disneyland tickets through Costco and a three-day trip/entry costs about the same as a 2-day trip so it's very economical to go for three days and that includes park entry and hotel. You can bring your own food into Disneyland and they have lockers that are quite large that you can rent to store stuff in if you need to. I do ride share to and from the park and since I buy through Costco and it has been a lot less expensive than parking at the park and also a lot less walking/time. The parking at the hotel is free (Costco travel packages have good packages with Disney) so I just leave the car there. I usually have one meal and one snack while I'm there, sit down restaurant experiences are going to cost you and you should plan ahead of time for them; I prefer a la cart and eat outside in the park. I've also redeemed freebies from the Costco page printouts and have gotten nice pins and lanyards per person which were a really nice touch to the travel package. That's how I do Disneyland.

Disney just isn't the place it used to be.  Ignore the cost for a moment.  You'll be spending the day with hot-sweaty masses, all stumbling around angry and confused trying to figure out the Disney app -- which you are REQUIRED to have / use for EVERYTHING except the toilets!  It's complicated, and comes with a fairly steep learning curve.  You'll have to pre-book / buy a place in line for most rides -- at least, the ones you'll actually wanna ride..  So, to summarize -- you'll pay a tidy fortune to sweat outside in the Florida summer with a bunch of strangers.  Pay even more to get on a few brief rides; then more again for some (actually pretty decent) food.  Oh, and then there's the lodgings....

I'm a FL resident my whole life & always get the weekday annual pass now called the Pixie Pass around $500 each for the whole year & you have the option to buy half down & the other half in 12 monthly payments which is what I do. Yes, Disney has absolutely priced out the middle and lower class. But, having gone for 35 years -- went in January for a week and a few days last week -- you never go for a day. Stay off site. Don't Hop or Lighting Lane. And MINIMUM 4 days. (Really, you need at least 2 days per park.) Plus, bring in your own snacks/drinks and only do quick-service with the app. And I will say that, as much as I 110% understand the criticism and dish it out given my long-term relationship with the Mouse, there is sooooooooooo much to do at Disney. Yea, the prices are high. But my goodness there really is just tons of stuff going on everywhere all the time. Like, a normal 2hr concert can be over $100 for a ticket. A day pass can be $150+, sure, but you can get nearly 12hrs of stuff to do. You'll feel like you got hit by a bus because the available content is exponential. It's impossible to even see 25% of it all even in a few days. Plus, the elephant in the room: this dude is a FL resident. Why the heck didn't he get annual passes? Or the FL tix special? Disney still takes care of FL peeps very well. He's partially to blame for the clickbait. And eating at Disney Springs? When you should be in the Park? No no no. Other variables: he went to Hollywood Studios. Based on date/day, lines can be double. I went to HS on 5/5 (a dreaded Monday) and yea -- it was busy. But that's because it was Star Wars weekend. I still put in 10hrs and made pretty good time even with (inflated) wait times. Anywho, it IS possible to do Disney on a budget. Just not like pre-2016. Gone are the days of the average family going every couple years. Unless you are going in debt or are flat-out wealthy, you are going every 5-10 years. And that's what they want. Less people paying more.

Disney is a rite-of-passage for parents. Took my family of four there 15 years ago and went back a few more times. Stayed at different hotels, from the Floridian to the low-end budgets. IMO, it's at least $1,000 a day for any kind of fun experience, cheaper and better if you book everything in advance. The higher the cost the fewer the crowds and nicer the experience, so ignore the cheap on-site closet-room hotels. Plan for at least a 3 or 4 day stint with a rest day or afternoons off. Without the fast pass and booking every character meal possible, it's just no fun. So save up your money, do it right, do it once then move on. After this you can spend your life on the beach cost and guilt free.

I do agree, to stay at a Disney Park Hotel and purchase theme park tickets, food and drink has got over the top expensive. But that doesn't mean you can't go. Just do your homework on alternative ways to do it. My daughter and I went last April. We stayed at a Disney Partner hotel for 4 nites and 5 full days. Flight, hotel, Airport Uber and park passes was under $2000 for 2 adults. The hotel provided free park shuttles. We went on every ride we wanted to and some of them several times. I brought granola bars and snacks from home. Ate at a quick service restaurants for lunch and shared the meal. Disney is very generous with food portions. We never paid for Lightening passes but as we stood in line, we watched families of 4 or more in those Lightening lanes and then we would calculate how much extra they spent just to be a little ahead of everyone else. Some of the attractions were clearly a waste of money to purchase Lightening Lane passes, but people still did it. So, I don't feel sorry for them when their credit card bill comes in. Disney is taking full advantage of the "ME FIRST"  mind set and the people who don't know how to say to no to their kids. Just like Cancun or any other destination vacation you can spend a little or spend a lot and still have a very similar and great experience. My advice, go during off peak seasons, stay at a partner hotel that offers free shuttle service, book discount airlines such as Spirit Air and if you are letting your children buy a souvenir, then give them a budget.

Me and my brother moved to Ft Lauderdale in Oct.1974. After the big layoffs! The first week here we jumped on our Bikes and  off to Disney. It was $1.00 to park and a day riding the rides was a token book of 12 tokens for 12 rides. I'm thinking $12.00.  Was also the entrance fee. Food was a bit expensive. We actually returned home and gave the left over tokens to friends that were planning to go there. Not sure but I think we spent no more than $40.00 a peace for the day including Disney Souvenirs. No shock there, I'm here as a College Programer and we cannot afford food most weeks as they give most of our earnings to their business partner American Campus community, everything around us is leased or owned by Disney so in reality we give nearly all of our checks back. When it comes to guests I'm just so sorry, we cast members do our best to make magic moments, giving out water and other things to the kids when I see they are over heating or upset to make the parents a little less stressed, but then I see all the areas where the guests are being manipulated or given sub par food, given the prices people pay to come here there is no reason you should be getting anything less then whats pictured on the menu and made properly. I love working here and even with all the cast discounts we get, bringing my family down once my program ends is impossible and there is no way most of us working here could ever afford to come ourselves even with the free park ticket. On behalf of Walt I'm sorry its come down to this, this is what he built Disney to combat and just sad to see that money is the real only winning factor anymore. We should be here to bring families together and bring some joy into their lives, not suck them dry with all the charges, and costs. I get operating costs and all that but you can make profit without making the most magical place on earth nonaccessable to a lot of families that the park was built to bring in.

I live in SoCal and my girls grew up at Disneyland from when they were toddlers.  I remember back in 2002, the SoCal pass was $99 with few block out days and I would pay an additional fee for the parking pass.  As they got older, I would pay around $800 for a fam of 4 for the Deluxe pass and back then you could get Fast passes to go to the front of the line for the popular rides for free.  It was so much fun, but when they were getting out of high school, they raised the price of the annual passes to where it wasn't worth it if you would be paying the equivalent of your annual car insurance to go there.  We went a few years ago because my neighbor works there and I feel sorry for anyone who would have paid.  The reservation system is annoying when we just used to go.  The lightening lane addition was too ridiculous and even with that, you have to pay an additional fee for certain rides.  At least three of my favorite rides were closed for maintenance and several rides, like Space Mountain and Indiana Jones, kept breaking down.  Remembering how it used to be, it just wasn't fun anymore.  I wouldn't pay to go there.  I feel for any family with small kids who have never gone there, where I wouldn't be surprised if they had to cough up $5k or more for several days.

Yes, Disney is expensive, but the dude was not making choices to keep costs down. All that alcohol, buying bottled water (you can get a cup of ice water for free), and a sit-down meal for five people?!  Also, he misunderstood the whole Lightning Lane concept. It's not three rides total for the day. It's three reservations at a time. You book three, and as soon as you use one of your rides, you can book a different ride as long as they are available.  I am not defending Disney and its high costs, but you have to research everything before you set foot in the park. Look at park trends like crowd calendars for your day to attend. Look up restaurants and their prices. Pack snacks and lunches if you can. See what merch you can buy outside the park. As one Disney vlogger puts it: If you fail to plan, you plan to fail.

As a long-time fan of Disney World, I find it sad that the average family cannot afford to go.  Another great sadness for me is: 1. Changing Splash Mountain for political/social reasons only 2. Getting rid of Tom Sawyer Island, Rivers of America, and the Riverboat ride.  These made the Magic Kingdom unique to other theme parks, and provided a link to the Walt-inspired rides of the past.  I've always felt that to make a park a success, it needed to provide something different than other parks.  Also, they had land available to put the new rides.   3. WDW and Disney in general should stay out of politics and social issues, and stick to just providing us the peaceful environment that made WDW unique and successful.  It used to be a place people could go to get away from all the chaos and schisms of our society and just enjoy a peaceful time.  No longer.   I believe Bob Iger put it best: "We're in the business to entertain, not to make statements".   Just my opinion, but I miss the "traditional" WDW. God Bless!

At this point, a trip to Disneyland is completely out of reach for anyone not living in a mansion.
Not saying Disney isn't pricey (and $1400 is $1400 no matter how you look at it), but what did he expect it would cost to take FIVE people to Disney World plus all-day meals, snacks, and a sit-down restaurant for dinner? Especially for only one day (as any theme park [let alone resort theme parks] will always charge more for single day admissions vs multiple), as he notes.   He spent an average of $280 per person, including all food. 2/3rds of that is the park admission (basically the same price as Universal), but that was probably higher than average for Disney because it was only 1 day (plus one assumes pricing is higher during summer months and near holidays). And parking, where $30 is pretty reasonable for destination sites like Disney, Universal, or sports arenas.   They spent $10/pp on lunch, which is less than it would cost to get a full meal at a movie theater, bowling alley, or performance/entertainment stadium. And another $20 total for roughly two snacks/drinks per person. Which is still pretty standard for entertainment venue snack pricing. And the rest was what sounds like a full entree and side (or appetizer) with a specialty alcoholic drink. You could go to a regular Applebees or TGIFridays and easily spent $35-45/pp for that.   Add all that up and it's a total that most people would logically expect for such an excursion. If you're looking for a cheap day outing with friends and family, you don't go to a destination resort theme park, you go to a local Six Flags park. But enjoy your theming being made almost entirely out of corrugated metal sheets instead of fully immersive worlds, because there are going to be trade-offs for the budget savings (and the snack food isn't going to be much cheaper, either).  Not to mention there ARE more cost effective ways to do Disney. He mentioned that he's a Florida resident, so, for example, it's quite possible that one of the Annual Passes would make sense for him. He'd probably pay 30% or more up-front but he'd save per trip if he came 2 or 3 times a year, plus whatever food/drink/parking discounts that come with that.   Either way, while there is clearly some sticker shock when you look at the final total, the breakdown per person for such activities really isn't that much out of the ordinary. But when you get it all at once, like, yeah, it's gonna add up.  And lastly, without intending to sound snarky (as people should be free to enjoy their trip however they want), but just as a general point that if budget is that much of an issue, maybe order some cokes, skip two of the margaritas, and buy that kid his lightsaber instead?
They could have done so many other things all summer with that money.   If you must go, buy your trinkets on International Blvd.

Is it expensive YES , but did you know on Disney website here in the states you can plan a trip up to a year in advance. Also once you figured out your trip (hotel,passes & meal plan)and next page will be your total, you will see all you have to pay at this time is the deposit, next line under that you will see that you have 11 month ( if your doing a year from now)to pay it off. What i do is divide total cost by how total time i get paid ( if it bi weekly or monthly), if you like the amount you see and can afford that amount on every payday you can have your vacation paid off in 11 months, if something come up and you have to cancel Disney will give you all of your money back except for your deposit.

Amusement park prices aren't going to get better. One of the drivers of the price they charge is how soon they close the park because of capacity during the day. There's a set amount of people the park can hold. They can't let in more people than that amount. Last time I went to Disney the park closed off new admittance in the early afternoon. This happened all three days. When this happens daily they raise prices to lessen demand and keep the numbers under capacity. It's simple supply and demand. If dad had done this he could have had the same trip for at least $400 less.  Just a sample of a few things you can do:  check online for cheaper admission days. Honestly, Disney is not that expensive. The current price for an adult 4 day Florida resident ticket this summer is $260. Kids ages 3-10 are half off this summer. That is literally half the cost of Universal parks. I was looking yesterday and saw rooms at the value hotels for a little over $135.   So realistically, a trip for a week is like a 1k budget. That is not at all unreasonable, not in the USA today! If you were out of state (not as a Floridian) you'd be paying airfare (very expensive), hotel, non-discounted ticket, and non-discounted hotel. Out of state visitors easily pay an extra 1-2k to see disney world. Disney is actually quite nice to Florida travelers because Disney always gave Floridians "good neighbors discounts" because Florida basically gave Disney everything they wanted on construction. Unlike LA or California who really didn't work with Disney, Florida more or less sold them enough land to have nightly fireworks, multiple parks, many resorts, etc.   So 4 years ago I think I bought that same ticket for $210. The tickets went up $50 in 4 years. Considering inflation on everything else I'd say that barely even rose for inflation. If you bought the day ticket it's $179. Under no circumstances does the day ticket ever make financial sense (except if you have the budget to do it and only want one day period, maybe a senior citizen). You either need to purchase a 4 day ticket, season pass, or annual. Universal too! It winds up cheaper.   It would cost me $1400 even to drive up to the Carolinas and stay in cabins, eat out. Idk. I think 1-2k is a realistic budget for ANY domestic trip. In fact, this year I can't fly to NYC or Chicago without paying $400.   I'm not about to fly on those planes crashing from the sky either. I want a real plane. A plane that passed inspection, so that's $400 on Delta/AA. Honestly, if you said airlines I'd agree with you. It's madness. I cannot even go to Denver any more because it costs what an international trip would to travel domestically between states. California costs the same as me flying to London. It's ridiculous airfare in this country! Europe pays half of us continentally.   *The prices listed are in June, July, August, and part of September they have $260 tickets and kids half off. I work at Disney California Adventure.  I get to go to either park whenever I want for free.  Thereâ€™s also a discount for some of the restaurants and swag.  How often do I go?  Maybe once or twice a year.  I think Disney is way overpriced and itâ€™s designed that way.  Before C-19, I kept an annual pass.  It has gone from $175 to $900 over the past 15 years.  As time went on everything started to have a price.  Before Lightning Lane, there was Fast Pass.  Fast Pass was free. Disney is absurdly expensive. Fortunately, I live in France, not too far from Disneyland Paris. French companies often offer various entertainment and/or travel benefits to their employees. For medium sized companies, that could be discount movie/theater/museum tickets, reduced gym memberships, etc. My wife works for a large corporation that privatizes Disneyland Paris annually beginning December as a Christmas/New Year party. It's a bit chilly that time of the year but there's unlimited coffee and hot chocolate as well as snacks. Nobody waits in line more than 10 minutes. I know other French corporations also privatize Disneyland Paris. We could also choose to go to a local amusement parc (Parc AstÃ©rix), the circus, etc. One year, we attended the "Lion King" musical. My wife hit the jackpot with her job cause we also have discounts for airlines, car rentals and hotels. Through her company, our children each get about 150 euro gift card as a Christmas gift. I'm not saying all this to brag but to tell you there are alternatives to the American way of life. In France, society is structured in a way that people can enjoy a certain quality of life without breaking the bank. It's a choice. Back in the US, I couldn't afford to have as much fun.
Any serious novel vacation (theme parks, airfare, hotel, concerts, etc.) factored out to about $1000 a day for my small family. I was shocked how comparable all the overall costs are for popular trips.  Camping vacations are a budget way to do things but camping is not super cheap anymore.

No matter where you go on vacation, you have to be financially savvy, you have to look for little ways to cut costs. The tickets are very expensive, that is not a cost you can really cut, but you don't have to stay at onsite resorts, there are many condos, homes and hotels around Disney outside of the park that is much much cheaper than staying at Disney resorts. Also, just buy small snacks there, don't have meals at those restaurants, again, there are many many restaurants along International Drive. Also, if you don't want to pay extra for fast passes, choose the rides that you absolutely must do so that your wait is worth it, and go from there. Disneys one of the least expensive vacations for me. As a Florida resident, you get an annual pass. You have no parking fee with that. Then you have to come a fair amount, but if you do, especially during weekdays and away from the busiest times, the area hotels are super affordable. We eat only a banana, or fruit at the parks to hold us over, and maybe once in a while an ice cream. We drink the free ice water they give to everyone, and eat outside of the park, or have a pic nick of sandwiches and chips in the car in a cooler. We really have a blast and if I had more money to spend, likely wouldn't enjoy it as much eating the restaurants, or at quick service. Of course my parents brought me back in the 70s and 80s, and this is how we always went. Some get to caught up in Disney everything, and you'll pay for thinking only Disney. Be tough like they were back in the day, and enjoy the park with a nice ham sandwich in the car.
